commander.name: Generalleutnant Ludwig Crüwell (until 29 May 1942), then Generalleutnant Walther Nehring
commander.previous_service: Crüwell: Commander XXXXI. Panzerkorps (Barbarossa 1941). Captured 29 May 1942 when Fieseler Storch shot down by South African fighters during Battle of Gazala. Nehring: Chief of Staff Panzergruppe Afrika (1941), then commanded DAK from 29 May 1942.
commander.notes: Critical command transition during Battle of Gazala. Rommel temporarily assumed direct DAK command 29 May until Nehring arrived. Crüwell promoted General der Panzertruppe 1 Feb 1942 before capture.

chief_of_staff.name: Oberst Fritz Bayerlein (until 1 June 1942)
chief_of_staff.notes: Promoted to Oberst 1 March 1942. Became Chief of Staff Panzerarmee Afrika on 1 June 1942 (replacing Gause who was wounded). Temporary DAK Ia during Gazala battle May-June 1942.

command.headquarters_location: Mobile HQ, Libya - Q2 1942: Gazala Line (April-May), Tmimi/Martuba (June)

Panzer III Ausf J.notes: Primary medium tank Q2 1942. Superior to British Crusader but outmatched by new Grant tanks arriving Egypt. 56 from 15. Pz, 35 from 21. Pz.

Panzer III Ausf H.notes: Older variant, being phased out. 12 from 15. Pz, 8 from 21. Pz.

Panzer IV Ausf F2.notes: CRITICAL NEW VARIANT - Long 75mm gun arrived Q1/Q2 1942. Devastating vs all British armor. Game-changer for Gazala battle. 26 from 15. Pz, 17 from 21. Pz.

Panzer IV Ausf F1.notes: Short-barreled variant for close support. Being replaced by F2. 19 from 21. Pz.

Panzer II Ausf C.notes: Reconnaissance tanks (28 from 15. Pz, 22 from 21. Pz). Numbers partially restored from Q1 losses.

Panzer I Ausf B.notes: Training/liaison only (5 from 15. Pz). Mostly phased out.

SdKfz 251.notes: 75 from 15. Pz, 70 from 21. Pz. Increased from Q1 with new deliveries.

Opel Blitz 3-ton.notes: Standard Wehrmacht truck (670 from 15. Pz, 550 from 21. Pz). Operational readiness improved from Q1 with workshops and new arrivals.

Mercedes-Benz L3000.notes: Heavy transport (435 from 15. Pz, 390 from 21. Pz)

Büssing-NAG.notes: Artillery tractor (235 from 15. Pz, 240 from 21. Pz)

Krupp L2H143.notes: Light cargo (170 from 15. Pz, 180 from 21. Pz)

Horch Kfz.15.notes: Staff cars (90 from 21. Pz, 5 corps HQ)

Recovery vehicles.notes: 42 from 15. Pz, 10 corps pool. Critical for Gazala battle tank recovery.

Fuel tankers.notes: 140 from 15. Pz, 20 from 21. Pz, 15 corps pool. Increased from Q1 for offensive operations.

Water tankers.notes: 120 from 15. Pz, 15 corps pool, 10 from various

Workshop vehicles.notes: 90 from 15. Pz, 25 from 21. Pz, 13 corps pool. Expanded capacity for offensive.

Ambulances.notes: 68 from 15. Pz, 14 from 21. Pz, 10 corps medical

10.5cm leFH 18.notes: 48 from 15. Pz, 28 from 21. Pz. Increased from Q1.

15cm sFH 18.notes: 22 from 15. Pz, 14 from 21. Pz. Reinforced for Gazala offensive.

5cm PaK 38.notes: Primary AT gun (28 from 15. Pz, 20 from 21. Pz). Increased numbers.

7.62cm PaK 36(r).notes: NEW - Captured Soviet F-22 guns re-bored for German ammo. Excellent penetration. 8 from 15. Pz, 6 from 21. Pz.

3.7cm PaK 35/36.notes: Light AT gun, being phased out (obsolete vs British armor). 6 from 15. Pz, 6 from 21. Pz.

8.8cm FlaK 18/36.notes: Dual-purpose AA/AT (14 from 15. Pz, 10 from 21. Pz). Reinforced for Gazala - decisive anti-tank weapon vs British armor.

2cm FlaK 38.notes: Improved light AA (10 from 15. Pz, 25 from 21. Pz)

fighters.note: Luftwaffe support provided at theater level by Fliegerführer Afrika (not organic to DAK)

reconnaissance.note: Fieseler Fi 156 Storch aircraft used for liaison by Rommel/Crüwell, not counted in corps TO&E

supply_logistics.supply_status: IMPROVED but still CONSTRAINED - Build-up for Operation Theseus (Gazala offensive). Extended supply lines from Tripoli (800km) and Benghazi (recaptured Jan 1942, now operational as forward port - 350km). British naval/air interdiction from Malta remains 25-35% convoy loss rate. Q2 1942 preparations: Fuel reserves 7-8 days (improved from Q1's crisis 5-6 days), ammunition 11-12 days, water 12-15L/man/day. Rommel accumulated supplies April-May for Gazala offensive scheduled 26 May 1942. Critical supply issue: British Grant tanks arriving Egypt (75mm gun outmatches all German tanks except Panzer IV F2). Supply base: Tripoli (main port) + Benghazi (forward port, critical for Gazala logistics). Rommel's gamble: Attack before British 8th Army fully equipped with Grants.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal desert (Cyrenaica) - Gazala Line defensive positions (April-May), then mobile operations Bir Hakeim → Tobruk (May-June). Terrain: gravel plains, rocky escarpments, wadis, minefields, no water sources.

subordinate_units.composition: Panzer-Regiment 8, Schützen-Regimenter 104/115, Kradschützen-Bataillon 15, Artillerie-Regiment 33, support units
subordinate_units.equipment_summary: 119 tanks (94 medium, 25 light), 76 field artillery, 48 AT guns, 2750 vehicles
subordinate_units.notes: Reinforced from Q1 1942 post-Crusader rebuild. Von Vaerst commanded continuously from Jan 1942. Tank strength increased to 119 (vs 86 Q1). Critical: 26 Panzer IV F2 with long 75mm gun - game-changer vs British armor.

subordinate_units.composition: Panzer-Regiment 5, Panzergrenadier-Regimenter 104/155, Aufklärungs-Abteilung 3, Artillerie-Regiment 155, support units
subordinate_units.equipment_summary: 109 tanks (79 medium, 30 light), 36 field artillery, 26 AT guns, 2295 vehicles
subordinate_units.notes: Von Bismarck commanded from Jan 1942. Tank strength increased to 109 (vs 79 Q1). 17 Panzer IV F2 long-barreled tanks provide critical anti-tank capability vs British Grant tanks arriving Egypt.

subordinate_units.equipment_summary: Radio trucks, telephone equipment, telegraph, motorcycles
subordinate_units.notes: Only organic corps troop unit. Essential for Gazala offensive coordination May-June 1942.

subordinate_units.composition: Light infantry regiments, reconnaissance, limited armor support
subordinate_units.equipment_summary: No tanks, motorized infantry, AT guns, field artillery
subordinate_units.notes: Attached to DAK for Gazala offensive (normally under Rommel's direct command). Former Division zbV Afrika, redesignated 90. leichte in late 1941. Provides flank security and mobile infantry.

tactical_doctrine.role: German armored exploitation corps in North Africa. Mobile striking force for Operation Theseus (Gazala offensive, 26 May - 21 June 1942). Combined arms coordination at corps level between panzer divisions, motorized infantry, and supporting arms. Q2 1942: Preparation for decisive offensive to capture Tobruk and drive into Egypt.
special_capabilities: 228 tanks (138% increase from Q1 1942 - 165 tanks to 228 tanks)
43 Panzer IV F2 with long 75mm gun - CRITICAL NEW CAPABILITY vs British Grant tanks
24 x 8.8cm FlaK guns in anti-tank role (33% increase from Q1)
14 x 7.62cm PaK 36(r) captured Soviet guns - excellent penetration
Mobile desert warfare expertise after 14 months combat experience
Combined arms coordination (tanks, motorized infantry, artillery, AT, AA)
Rommel's tactical genius at corps-level combined arms operations
tactical_innovations: Panzer IV F2 long 75mm gun - revolutionary capability vs all British armor (Grant, Crusader, Matilda)
Mobile AT gun screens with 8.8cm FlaK + 5cm PaK 38 + 7.62cm PaK 36(r) to lure British armor into kill zones
Rapid exploitation using sun compass navigation and aggressive reconnaissance
'Left Hook' flanking maneuver at Gazala (26 May 1942) - sweep around Bir Hakeim to envelop British forces
Concentration of armor at Schwerpunkt (decisive point) - classic German doctrine
Mobile workshops for rapid battlefield repairs (critical for sustained operations)
Deception: Rommel delayed Gazala offensive to April then May to maximize supply build-up and surprise
Combined German-Italian armored operations (DAK + XX Mobile Corps coordination)
known_issues: British Grant tanks arriving Egypt with 75mm gun - outmatch all German tanks except Panzer IV F2 (only 43 of 228 tanks)
Extended supply lines (Tripoli 800km, Benghazi 350km) via coastal road vulnerable to British air/naval interdiction
Malta-based RAF/RN submarines destroy 25-35% of Axis supply convoys
Fuel reserves 7-8 days (improved from Q1 but still inadequate for sustained offensive beyond Tobruk)
Water scarcity in desert - 12-15L/man/day minimum requirement
Panzer III J 50mm gun marginal vs British Grant frontal armor (51mm @ 60° = 102mm effective)
Limited spare parts - vehicles/tanks cannibalized for critical components
Vulnerability of soft-skinned vehicles to British air attacks (RAF air superiority growing)
No organic air support - dependent on Fliegerführer Afrika at theater level (Luftwaffe overstretched Russia/Malta/North Africa)
Crüwell captured 29 May 1942 during Gazala battle - command disruption at critical moment
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Tropical uniforms (khaki), sand filters on all vehicles, desert tires, increased water capacity (tankers), sun compass/dead reckoning navigation, vehicle recovery emphasis (limited replacements), water discipline (12-15L/man/day), capture of British supply dumps essential (Gazala offensive plan included seizing British supply depots), mobile workshops for field repairs, aggressive reconnaissance to find water sources/supply dumps/enemy positions. Q2 1942 emphasis: Stockpiling supplies April-May for Gazala offensive, workshops prepared for sustained operations.

scenario_suitability: Operation Theseus - Battle of Gazala (26 May - 21 June 1942) - DAK's offensive to capture Tobruk
Gazala 'Left Hook' (26-27 May 1942) - DAK sweep around Bir Hakeim to envelop British forces
Battle of 'The Cauldron' (28 May - 11 June 1942) - DAK trapped in British minefield, desperate defense
Breakout from The Cauldron (11-13 June 1942) - DAK smashes British counterattacks
Knightsbridge Box battles (12-13 June 1942) - British armored brigade destroyed
Capture of Tobruk (20-21 June 1942) - DAK seizes fortress and massive supply dumps
Pursuit into Egypt (22-30 June 1942) - DAK drives to El Alamein
Desert patrol actions and reconnaissance battles (April-May 1942 pre-offensive)
special_rules: Rommel leadership bonus: +2 to DAK units within 8km of Rommel's HQ (legendary commander)
Panzer IV F2 long 75mm: Exceptional vs all British armor - penetrates Grant/Crusader/Matilda at all ranges
8.8cm FlaK guns in AT role: Devastating vs all British armor - morale penalty to British armor within 2km of 88s
Superior combined arms coordination: +2 to coordination checks (14 months desert experience)
Desert warfare expertise: +2 to navigation/survival checks
Extended supply lines penalty: -1 to sustained operations after 5 days without resupply (improved from Q1)
Gazala Offensive surprise: +2 to initiative rolls for first 3 turns (British expecting defensive posture)
Crüwell capture (29 May): -1 coordination penalty turns 4-6 (command transition to Nehring)
Tank recovery priority: +2 to battlefield recovery checks (mobile workshops doubled effort)
Fuel crisis potential: Roll supply check every 3rd turn - failure = -1 operational movement next turn
historical_engagements: Gazala Line stalemate (February-May 1942) - Preparation and deception operations
Operation Theseus - Battle of Gazala (26 May - 21 June 1942) - Rommel's masterpiece offensive
Gazala 'Left Hook' (26-27 May 1942) - 10,000 vehicles sweep around Bir Hakeim in night march
Battle of 'The Cauldron' (28 May - 11 June 1942) - DAK trapped, destroyed British 150th Brigade Box to create supply route
Destruction of British 2nd and 4th Armoured Brigades (12-13 June 1942) - Knightsbridge battles
Siege and capture of Tobruk (20-21 June 1942) - 33,000 British/Commonwealth prisoners, 2,000 vehicles, vast supply dumps
Pursuit to Egypt and First Battle of El Alamein (late June-July 1942) - Overextended advance halted

source: The Rommel Papers - PRIMARY SOURCE: Tank strength Gazala offensive: 228 tanks operational 26 May 1942 (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
The Rommel Papers - Gazala battle dates, operations, Crüwell capture 29 May, Tobruk capture 21 June (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
The Rommel Papers - Supply situation Q2 1942: 'Fuel for 7-8 days, ammunition adequate' (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
Tessin Band 14 - Deutsches Afrikakorps organizational structure Q2 1942 (Tier 1, 85% confidence)
Nafziger Collection - German OOB North Africa 1942 Q2 (Tier 1, 82% confidence)
Feldgrau.com - DAK unit history, Crüwell command until 29 May 1942, Nehring from 29 May (Tier 2, 80% confidence)
Cross-referenced: Crüwell capture 29 May 1942 - Rommel Papers, Mitcham, Playfair (Official History)
Cross-referenced: Panzer IV F2 arrival Q1/Q2 1942 - Jentz (Panzer Truppen), Spielberger
Cross-referenced: Gazala battle dates/operations - Playfair (Official History), Barnett (Desert Generals)
Calculated: Tank totals (228) from Q1 baseline (165) + Q2 reinforcements (63 net increase)
Calculated: Personnel (28,650) from division aggregation + Q2 reinforcements
Calculated: Supply/logistics from Rommel Papers Q2 1942 entries (Gazala preparation April-May)
Schema v3.1.0: supply_logistics and weather_environment sections complete
validation.validated_by: Claude Code Agent - Autonomous Extraction Q2 1942
notes: Q2 1942 critical quarter: Preparation and execution of Operation Theseus (Gazala offensive)
Tank strength 228 (38% increase from Q1 165 tanks) - reinforcements arrived April-May 1942
Panzer IV F2 with long 75mm gun: 43 of 228 tanks (19%) - CRITICAL new capability vs British Grant tanks
Command transition: Crüwell captured 29 May → Nehring assumed command during peak of Gazala battle
Supply situation improved from Q1 crisis (5-6 days fuel) to Q2 build-up (7-8 days fuel) - still inadequate for sustained offensive
Gazala offensive 26 May - 21 June 1942: Rommel's masterpiece - captured Tobruk 21 June, promoted Generalfeldmarschall same day
Historical significance: Rommel's greatest victory - drove British 8th Army to El Alamein, threatened Egypt/Suez Canal
